results.title: Hot water; Safety last
results.creator_credit: Fred C Newmeyer, Bob Hoag and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “New Versions of Comedy Classics”
This film is a new print of two old comedy films. ‘Hot Water’, made in 1924, is about Harold taking a live turkey on a trolley ride and then taking his in-laws for an equally hysterical ride in his new car. Also stars Jobyna Ralston, Josephine Crowell, Charles A. Stevenson and Mickey McBan. Written by Tommy Gray and John Grey. The second film, called ‘Safety Last’, was made in 1923 and is about Harold going to the big city to make his fortune and includes the scene “Harold Lloyd on the clock”. Also stars Mildred Davis and Bill Strothers. Written by Jean C. Havez and Sam Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fred C Newmeyer, Bob Hoag and Time-Life Films

results.title: The Freshman
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “New Versions of Comedy Classics”.
This film is a new restored print of a 1925 comedy. “The Freshman” is about country boy Harold who goes to college and, after many tribulations, saves the day when he makes the winning touchdown at the big game.

results.title: La Trobe Cottage
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Ampol Petroleum Ltd and National Trust
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
A look at La Trobe Cottage, Victoria’s first Government House. Brought out from England, it was assembled on a foundation of hand-made bricks.

results.title: Como
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Looks at the National Trust property, Como, giving a description of the buildings and a brief history. Built prior to 1851, it was the home of the Armitage family until acquisition by the National Trust. Script by Glenn Berry.

results.title: Australian Heritage: holly green country
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and National Trust
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Shows the oldest existing homestead in Victoria, Holly Green farm 1836. Also Rupertswood 1870, and Glen Eira homestead 1857. Written by Eileen Berry.

results.title: Australian heritage [compilation]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Old Parramatta - after Sydney, the oldest city in Australia. Historic Hawksbury - the valley was settled shortly after the arrival of the First Fleet in 1788. Elizabeth Bay House - an outstanding example of colonial architecture. Goolwa - a town near the mouth of the Murray in South Australia. Kurralta - a famous historic house near Adelaide. Marion - a River Murray paddle steamer.

results.title: Australian heritage [compilation]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Ornamental iron - fine examples of the iron work. Bathurst - 100 miles west of Sydney is a town with many fine Victorian Renaissance buildings. Iron lace - imported and locally made, was more extensively used in Australia than anywhere else in the world. Aboriginal rock art - is preserved by the National Parks and Wild Life Service of N.S.W.

results.title: Vanishing valley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
A plea by the National Trust to preserve the beauty of the upper reaches of the Yarra, which are at present polluted by rubbish and chemical waste from factories.

results.title: Peninsular pioneers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Describes the country buildings of Arthur’s Seat or McCrae Cottage 1844, the Church of St James the Less 1865, Heronswood 1871, and Baragunda 1866.
